qas.question: What type of software began to emerge following the release of Intel-based Macs?
At what speed do programs such as VirtualBox allow Microsoft Windows to run on Macs?
What is possible to run by using Boot camp, even though it is not condoned by Apple?
What do Macs lack that makes them unable to run many legacy PC operating systems?
What type of hardware began to emerge following the release of Intel-based Macs?
At what speed do programs such as VirtualBox allow Microsoft DOS to run on Macs?
What is possible to run by using Boot camp, even though it is not condoned by Microsoft?
What do Macs lack that makes them able to run many legacy PC operating systems?
What do Macs have that makes them unable to run many legacy PC operating systems?

context: Following the release of Intel-based Macs, <a0_0><b4_0>third-party platform virtualization<b4_0/><a0_0/> software such as Parallels Desktop, VMware Fusion, and VirtualBox began to emerge. These programs allow users to run Microsoft Windows or previously Windows-only software on Macs <a1_0><b5_0>at near native speed<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Apple also released Boot Camp and Mac-specific Windows drivers that help users to install Windows XP or Vista and natively dual boot between Mac OS X and Windows. Though not condoned by Apple, it is possible to run <a2_0><b6_0>the Linux operating system<b6_0/><a2_0/> using Boot camp or other virtualization workarounds. Unlike most PCs, however, Macs are unable to run many legacy PC operating systems. In particular, Intel-based macs lack <a3_0>the <b7_0><b8_0>A20 gate<b8_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/>.
